entry.title: Developing a Shell Plugin for SAP Build Work Zone to Display Custom Notifications on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction 

Unlocking Custom Experiences in SAP Build Work Zone: Shell Plugin in Action
In today’s digital workplace, personalization is key. This article showcases how to enhance SAP Build Work Zone with a custom shell plugin that brings tailored notifications right to the user’s fingertips. Using a Multi-Target UI5/CAP application, we’ll demonstrate how to create, manage, and surface custom alerts—seamlessly integrated into your Work Zone experience.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

To replicate this you should have a base knowledge of SAP BTP, JS, SAPUI5 and SAP CAP, I will not go deep down in to how to generate a project in BAS, or create an instance in SAP BTP. 

***GITHUB URL REMOVED BY MODERATION***

Project Architecture

 

Backend/Frontend App Development:

Generate a regular SAP CAP application

Firstly I've created a primitave data structure under db/schema.cds

namespace my.Notification;

entity Notification {
    key ID : UUID;
    type: String(30);
    title: String;
    message: String;
}

 Than a service at srv/service.cds:

using { my.Notification as my } from '../db/schema';

service NotificationService {
    entity Notification as projection on my.Notification;
}

And the backend is almost done, now add an app router and a sapui5 freestyle base app to the project.

Now let's add a form to create and delete the notifications under app/<app name>/webapp/view/<view name>.view.xml:

 

Spoiler
Remember to correct the controller name if you copy the code

 

<mvc:View
    controllerName="com.sap.shellnotificationsender.controller.MyView"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:form="sap.ui.layout.form"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">

    <Toolbar>
        <Title text="{i18n>title}" />
    </Toolbar>

    <Shell id="mainShell">
        <VBox class="sapUiSmallMargin">
            <form:SimpleForm
                    editable="true"
                    layout="ResponsiveGridLayout"
                    labelSpanL="1" labelSpanM="2"
                    adjustLabelSpan="false"
                    columnsL="3" columnsM="3"
                    class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom">

                    <Label text="Type" />
                    <ComboBox id="newType" selectedKey="information">
                        <core:Item key="Warning" text="Warning" />
                        <core:Item key="Success" text="Success" />
                        <core:Item key="Information" text="Information" />
                        <core:Item key="Error" text="Error" />
                        <core:Item key="Alert" text="Alert" />
                        <core:Item key="Confirm" text="Confirm" />
                    </ComboBox>

                    <Label text="Title" />
                    <Input id="newTitle" />

                    <Label text="Message" />
                    <Input id="newMessage" />

                    <Label text="" />
                    <Button text="Add Notification"
                        press="onAddNotification"
                        type="Emphasized"/>
                </form:SimpleForm>

            <!-- Table Section -->
            <Table id="shellNotificationsTable" items="{/Notification}">
                <columns>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Delete" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Type" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Title" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Message" />
                    </Column>
                </columns>

                <items>
                    <ColumnListItem>
                        <cells>
                            <Button icon="sap-icon://delete" type="Negative" press="deleteRow" />
                            <Text text="{type}" />
                            <Text text="{title}" />
                            <Text text="{message}" />
                        </cells>
                    </ColumnListItem>
                </items>
            </Table>
        </VBox>
    </Shell>
</mvc:View>

As next let's implement the controller that manages the view with all the necessary notification creation/deletion methods:

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/m/MessageBox",
	"sap/m/MessageToast"
], (Controller, MessageBox, MessageToast) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("com.sap.shellnotificationsender.controller.MyView", {
        onInit() {

        },

        deleteRow: function (oEvent) {
			var oContext = oEvent.getSource().getBindingContext().getObject();
			console.log(oContext);
			MessageBox.confirm("Are your sure you want to delete this message?", {
				title: "Confirm",
				onClose: function (sAction) {
					if (sAction === "OK") {
						this.onDeleteSpecificRecord(oContext)
					}
				}.bind(this),
				actions: [
					MessageBox.Action.OK,
					MessageBox.Action.CANCEL
				],
				emphasizedAction: MessageBox.Action.OK
			})
		},

		onDeleteSpecificRecord: function (oRecord) {
			var oDataModel = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel();
			var oBusyDialog = new sap.m.BusyDialog({
				title: "Deleting Record",
				text: "Please Wait ..."
			})
			oBusyDialog.open();
			oDataModel.delete(`/Notification('${oRecord.ID}')`)
				.then(() => {
					console.log("Record deleted successfully");
				})
				.catch((error) => {
					console.error("Deletion failed:", error);
				})
				.finally(() => {
					this.getView().byId("shellNotificationsTable").getBinding("items").refresh();
					oBusyDialog.close();
				});
		},

		onAddNotification: function () {
			const sType = this.byId("newType").getValue();
			const sTitle = this.byId("newTitle").getValue();
			const sMessage = this.byId("newMessage").getValue();

			this.byId("shellNotificationsTable").getBinding("items").create({
				"type": sType,
				"title": sTitle,
				"message": sMessage
			}).created().then(function() {
				MessageToast.show("Created")
			})
		}
    });
});

The last thing to do is to add all the features that you need to the application, like HANA DB, xsuaa in my case, to do so just run

cds add hana
cds add xsuaa

And like this is the app ready, let's deploy it, firstly login to Cloud Foundry

cf login

then right click on the mta.yaml file -> "Build MTA Project"

then go to mta_archives/<archive name>.tar right click and "Deploy MTA Project".

BTP Steps

To connect to the app from the shell plugin you need to create a SAP BTP Destination, 

to do so go to <BTP Subaccount> -> Cloud Foundry -> <Your space> -> <Your app name>-srv and copy it's address, that's your destination URL

Now you need to get the authentication data for the Destination

Go to <Your CF Space> -> Instances -> <Your app name>-auth -> <Your app name>-auth-key 

Copy these:

Client ID, Client secret and url (Access Token URL)

Now go back to your Subaccount and create a new destination with your data:

  • URL:  app-srv URL
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • ClientID: ClientID
  • Client secret: Client secret
  • Token service URL type: Dedicated
  • Token Service URL: <Access token URL>/oauth/token

After this add these 2 parameters:

  • HTML5.DynamicDestination: true
  • WebIDEEnabled: true

With this step is the backend development concluded.

Shell Plugin Development:

Firstly a general explanation about shell plugins. Shell Plugins are UI5 Applications that allow to add new Elements to SAP Build Work Zone/Fiori Launchpad like Headers, Footers, menu items etc.

To create a shell plugin generate a plain UI5 Basic Freestyle application with the "Template Wizard" in Business Application Studio.

There are a couple of things to modify in the manifest.json to make a a Shell Plugin:

Inside sap.app change the type to component:

"type": "component"

In sap.app>crossNavigation hide the launcher:

"crossNavigation": {
      "inbounds": {
        "Shell-plugin": {
          "semanticObject": "Shell",
          "action": "plugin",
          "title": "{{Shell-plugin.flpTitle}}",
          "hideLauncher": true,
          "icon": "",
          "signature": {
            "parameters": {},
            "additionalParameters": "allowed"
          }
        }
      }
    },

 Add this part under after sap.cloud:

"sap.flp": {
    "type": "plugin"
  }

  This way the Shell Plugin configuration is completed, now let's add our newly created Destination

in sap.app>dataSources add this:

"NotificationService": {
        "uri": "/ShellNotifications/odata/v4/notification/",
        "type": "OData",
        "settings": {
          "odataVersion": "4.0"
        }
      }

and in sap.ui5>models: 

"Notification": {
        "dataSource": "NotificationService",
        "settings": {
          "synchronizationMode": "None",  
          "operationMode": "Server",
          "autoExpandSelect": true
        },
        "type": "sap.ui.model.odata.v4.ODataModel"
      }

and as last thing add this route to your xs-app.json file:

 

Spoiler
Remember: the order of the routes in xs-app matters, if you add it at the end it might not be resolved correctly by the app router

 

{
      "source": "^/ShellNotifications/(.*)$",
      "destination": "ShellNotifications",
      "target": "$1",
      "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
      "csrfProtection": true
    },

Now finally you can add the code that displays the notifications, to do so open the Component.js file and add the following code to the init method:

const oModel = this.getModel("Notification");

            oModel.bindList("/Notification").requestContexts().then((aContexts) => {
                const aData = aContexts.map(oContext => oContext.getObject());
                for (const el of aData) {
                    const nType = el["type"];
                    const nTitle = el["title"];
                    const nMessage = el["message"]
                    if (nType === "Information") {
                        MessageBox.information(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        });
                    } else if (nType === "Alert") {
                        MessageBox.alert(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Confirm") {
                        MessageBox.confirm(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Error") {
                        MessageBox.error(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Success") {
                        MessageBox.success(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Warning") {
                        MessageBox.warning(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    }
                }
            }).catch((err) => {
                console.error("Failed to load notifications:", err);
            });

 And like this is the development finished, the last step is to deploy it and add to WorkZone.

To build it do the same steps as with the MTA app:

  • right click on the mta.yaml file -> "Build MTA Project"
  • go to mta_archives/<archive name>.tar right click and "Deploy MTA Project".

SAP Build Work Zone Steps

Although the SAP Build Work Zone standard and advanced edition have some UI differences, the steps are the same for both of them.

All the steps performed below are done on SAP Build Work Zone advanced edition.

Start by going to the Administration Console -> External Integration -> Business Content -> Content Manager

 Than open the content channel and update the "HTML5 Apps"

 After that go Content Explorer and click Content Explorer (In the current UI it's a button in the header)

Select "HTML5 Apps" and add the new Shell Plugin that you just created

 To be able to see the plugin, assign it to a role, in my case it's the "Everyone" role, you can find it in the Content Manager

 After you've done that you should be able to see your new shell plugin the SAP Build Work Zone's launchpad

 If you don't see it try to open the page in an "Anonymous" Tab and check the developer console

Conclusion

What we’ve built here is just a glimpse into what’s possible with shell plugins in SAP Build Work Zone. By integrating a custom notification system, we’ve shown how easily you can extend the platform to better fit your customers’ needs. But this is only the starting point.

There’s a wide range of enhancements you can explore next—such as targeting specific users with personalized notifications, adding actionable buttons to each alert, or even integrating with external systems to trigger real-time messages. The flexibility of shell extensions offers endless opportunities to enrich the Work Zone experience and tailor it to your organization’s workflows.

So go ahead—experiment, extend, and elevate your Work Zone.

entry.title: SAP HANA PARAMETERS TUNING FOR PERFORMANCE OPTIMIZATION
entry.content:
I am writing this blog for publishing on the SAP Community, focused on SAP HANA Performance Optimization. It's structured to be informative, experience-driven, and valuable to a technical audience.

SAP HANA is known for its lightning-fast in-memory computing power, but like any high-performance engine, it requires Parameters tuning, Maintenance, and optimization to ensure it's running at its peak. Whether you're an SAP Basis Consultant, HANA Admin, or someone involved in performance analysis, this guide will walk you through proven techniques and practical tips that have worked in real-world SAP projects. HANA Parameters Tuning required in case of Migration, Implementation Projects as well as Support AMS Project.

When we are migrated to SAP HANA or Installing New Hana Database, all parameters are default parameters which may not perform as per your requirement or as per your landscape So we need to tune those parameters for system performance. SAP HANA parameter tuning for performance optimization involves configuring various system settings to maximize efficiency. Key areas include data modeling, load optimization, query optimization, and utilizing features like partitioning and columnar storage. Fine-tuning these parameters can significantly impact data processing speed, memory usage, and overall system responsiveness

Why HANA Performance Optimization Matters ?

In an enterprise environment, poor performance can impact business processes, reporting speed, and even downstream applications. Optimizing HANA ensures:

  • Faster analytics and reporting
  • Better end-user experience
  • Reduced infrastructure costs
  • Longer hardware lifecycle

 SAP S/4HANA End-to-End Performance Overview

SAP S/4HANA Architecture consist of 3-tiers, a SAP Fiori UI5 frontend, an SAP S/4HANA ABAP backend and a SAP HANA database

Database and ABAP processing times are two primary components of ABAP response time. Effects of pushing code to SAP HANA changes standard metrics of ABAP and database time as well as the common SAP R/3  and S/4 standard of 1 second per Dialog step.

Some SAP HANA features and ABAP coding that contribute to backend response times.

  • Core Data Services (CDS)
  • ABAP Managed Database Procedures
  • Compatibility views
  • Parallel processing in SAP HANA
  • Columnar in-memory database

End-to-End performance of an SAP S/4HANA system is spread across 4 layers: SAP Fiori UI, SAP S/4HANA  ABAP layer, CDS views and SAP HANA

Below are 11 Points need to perform for HANA Performance Optimization.

1. Monitor Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)

Start with regular monitoring of essential KPIs:

Metric

Tool/Transaction

What to Look For

Memory Usage

HANA Studio, HDB Admin, ST06

High memory without releases

CPU Utilization

top, vmstat, ST06

CPU consistently >85%

Disk Read/Write

iostat, HANA Cockpit

Spikes during peak load

Expensive Statements

ST03N, ST05, SQL Plan Cache

Long-running or unoptimized SQLs

Delta Merge Status

M_DELTA_MERGE_STATISTICS

High frequency or failing merges

2. Use the HANA Cockpit and HANA Studio Wisely

Both tools provide dashboards to analyze:

  • Memory load and footprint
  • Active sessions and threads
  • Expensive SQL statements
  • Alerts (CPU, Disk, Memory, column unloads)

Tip: Configure alerting thresholds to get notified before performance degrades.

3. Data Volume Management (DVM)

Large tables or outdated data can slow down performance.

  • Archive or purge old data
  • Split large tables into partitions
  • Use RSDA_DATA_SELECT or DBACOCKPIT to find large table

4. List of Parameter Recommendations in SAP HANA Environments (Important)

Prevent runaway queries (e.g. 10–20 GB per query)

Full and delta backups configured and validated

5. Best practice configuration checks for SAP HANA.

Run the HANA_Configuration_Parameters_1.00.90+ or HANA_Configuration_Parameters_2.00.040+.txt script, which is maintained in SAP note 1969700 SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA (below is a sample output) , Do Mini Checks in System and check all parameters and set SAP recommended parameters accordingly.

Additional Info

  • These checks can be executed on the SYSTEMDB and on each Tenant DB (for Hana 2.0) - but are particularly important for the Tenant DB's
  • Each Tenant DB can have different parameter values set, depending on each customer requirement
  • It is recommended that each Tenant has these best practice parameter values in place before productive use starts i.e. run these checks immediately after installation or upgrade, implement parameter value recommendations and test that these meet your business requirements
  • The output of the script will only show Hana parameters which are not currently set as per best practice recommendations
  • It will give recommended parameter value settings and note references on the particular parameter/topic area
  • In the P (Priority) column, you can see the most critical parameters to be set - 1 has highest priority
  • It will give actual SQL commands (ALTER statements) to set the parameter to the required value
  • And also an UNDO_COMMAND should you need to revert the parameter
  • If opening a support case with SAP Technical Support, providing the output of this parameter check will help to speed up the analysis
  • Check out the SAP HANA Configuration Parameter Reference: Index guide as per your HANA revision
  • In List SAP also provides Commands to modify Parameters. Just need to run those commands at SQL in HANA Cockpit or Studio.

6. List of Parameters Tuning at Linux OS Level.

7. OS and Infrastructure Checks

  • Ensure proper NUMA configuration
  • Keep kernel and firmware updated
  • Use SSDs for /hana/data and /hana/log
  • Monitor swap usage: HANA hates swapping!

 9. Smart Delta Merge Strategy

Delta merges can cause spikes in memory and CPU.

  • Check M_DELTA_MERGE_STATISTICS regularly
  • Avoid frequent merges on volatile tables
  • Automate delta merge scheduling for off-peak times

Tip: Always back up config and consult SAP notes before changing parameters.

To keep control of the delta merge we keep our table enable AUTOMERGE but in the data loading time we keep it into disable auto merge and enable smart merge for large volume tables.

Auto Merge :  HANA keeps a compressed “main” store of column tables and an uncompressed “delta” store, for new items. Periodically, a process called mergedog combines the two in a DELTA MERGE process. Sometimes however your tables may not be configured to automerge (you can issue ALTER TABLE table name ENABLE AUTOMERGE), and occasionally merged fails and you have to restart HANA. This can cause the delta store to become very large, and because it is uncompressed, this is a big issue if you don’t have much RAM.

Below Command:-

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ALTER TABLE “SCHEMA”.”TABLE” DISABLE AUTOMERGE;

IMPORT FROM ‘/sapmnt/log/test.ctl’ WITH THREADS 120 BATCH 200000;

MERGE DELTA OF “SCHEMA”.”TABLE”;

ALTER TABLE “SCHEMA”.”TABLE ENABLE AUTOMERGE;

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

10. Use SAP Recommendations & Notes.

SAP regularly publishes SAP HANA performance-related notes. Some helpful ones include:

  • SAP Note 1999997 – SAP HANA Troubleshooting Guide (FAQ: SAP HANA Memory)
  • SAP Note 2399079 – Elimination of hdbparam in HANA 2
  • SAP Note 2186744 FAQ: SAP HANA Parameters.
  • SAP Note 2600030 Parameter Recommendations in SAP HANA Environments
  •  SAP Note 1969700 - SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA - (For Mini Checks),
  • SAP HANA Troubleshooting and Performance Analysis Guide for your SAP HANA Platform revision at https://help.sap.com/viewer/p/SAP_HANA_PLATFORM

  • Clean up old logs and trace files.
  • Reclaim memory, data volume and logs (ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM LOGS, MEMORY, DATAVOLUME)
  • Remove obsolete backups from disk

 Conclusion

SAP HANA is a powerful platform, but like any high-performance machine, it needs care and attention. By combining smart monitoring, regular analysis, and data management best practices, you can keep your system running efficiently and support your business-critical operations smoothly.

entry.title: SAP Joule for Beginners: Everything You Need to Know - All at one stop!
entry.content:
This blog is for anyone in the SAP domain — from consultants to architects — who is curious about SAP Joule and wants to understand how it works. You're in the right place!

Disclaimer: This blog is based on publicly available information as of 24th July 2025, along with my personal interpretation. Sources of all referenced information, where available, are quoted in the REFERENCE section of this blog.

Topics covered in this blog are:

Welcome to the world of SAP Joule! Let's decode it into chunks! 

"How can I help you? 

Talk to me naturally. For example, 'What are my task for today?"

 

This is how Joule greets you in first place!

Joule — a name derived from the unit of energy — is here to energize our business processes, save valuable time, and simplify even the most tedious tasks resulting in greater efficiency and a noticeable uplift in the quality of our work.

SECTION 1: Understanding key terminologies and concepts:

Let’s cover some basic artificial intelligence terms before diving deeper into Joule for better understanding.

  • Artificial intelligence (AI) is a technology that mimics human reasoning and behavior, enabling machines to make decisions on their own. By processing large volumes of data, AI can understand speech, identify patterns and trends, solve problems proactively, and forecast future outcomes.

  • GenAI also known as generative AI is a model where it can create new content which can either be text, image, audio and video based on the existing content that it already has.

  • LLM (Large language Model) is the specific model (like GPT, PaLM, LLaMA) that powers the text generation part of GenAI. It is a type of artificial intelligence model that is trained to understand and generate human-like language. It's designed to read, summarize, translate, predict, or generate text based on the input it receives. Eg, When we ask ChatGPT a question, it's an LLM that's interpreting our text and generating a relevant, natural-sounding response.

  • AI copilot is a virtual assistant that helps business application users complete tasks more easily through a conversational interface. It uses generative AI to understand requests, take actions, and offer insights from business data. AI Copilots use LLMs to understand natural language and assist users in real time.The answer that is provided to the user is limited to training data against LLMs. "Large" refers to the massive amount of data and the billions of parameters the model is trained on.

  • Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): In SAP world, customer specific data cannot be used to train the LLMs. And hence we need a better way to retrieve the desired outcomes without breaching the customer's data privacy. This is where RAG comes into picture. It is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). This is done through Document Grounding. As a part of preparation of RAG, it provided with SAP and customer specific documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are then chunked into smaller parts and are then embedded into dense, continuous vectors—known as embeddings—which represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query. This information is passed to the LLM as prompts during runtime rather than getting it trained. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data. Rather, they get Grounded against customer specific data. 

  • HANA Vector Database enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords.

    Image source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uiv29xYlXvQ

  • For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. For instance, when a user asks about their company's paternity leave policy, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.

SECTION 2: What is SAP Joule and what are its use cases in the SAP world

SAP Joule is an AI copilot from SAP. Powered by SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform), it serves as a virtual assistant that leverages generative AI to understand and respond to user requests within SAP systems.

Before diving deeper, Let's understand some of the use cases of SAP Joule. Below are some of the end-user prompts that can be sent to Joule, where it responds appropriately using natural language processing. These examples are sourced from SAP's official Joule product pages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html#agility-for-all

Why Joule?

Joule is SAP domain-specific and is integrated with SAP’s suite of products, ensuring seamless interaction and data exchange across the SAP portfolio. It is also a responsible AI solution, with a strong emphasis on industry-specific regulations and standards. As a result, Joule is a more Relevant, Reliable, and Responsible AI copilot for SAP.

As specified earlier, the LLMs in Joule are not actually trained to respond to SAP user queries. Instead, Joule use document grounding through RAGe (Retrieval-Augmented Generation for enterprise) for unstructured data, and the SAP Knowledge Graph for structured data, enabling it to provide more comprehensive responses by referencing business documents from both SAP and third-party repositories , while LLMs are used to add natural language rather than the actual context in the response that is sent to user by Joule. That is, Grounding uses a customer’s own knowledge sources (e.g., travel policies, enablement content, service manuals, FAQs, etc.) to supplement the capabilities of Large language models (LLMs). This gives Joule a unique understanding of SAP data and processes, allowing it to respond more reliably than any other AI copilot.

Joule is seamlessly integrated into various SAP cloud solutions to help users work more efficiently across different business functions, such as:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition

  • SAP SuccessFactors

  • SAP Ariba

  • SAP Sales Cloud

  • SAP Customer Experience solutions

  • SAP Concur

  • SAP ABAP Cloud

However, it is worth noting that Joule is not available for on-premise solutions.

Thus the main advantages of SAP Joule include:

  • Enhanced decision-making

  • Accelerated end-to-end business processes

  • Personalized UI with inherited user authorizations

  • Advanced analytics

  • Contextual awareness

  • Ability to meet diverse business needs

Business application supported by SAP Joule:

SAP Joule runs on the AI Foundation of SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) and supports a wide range of business application such as Finance, Procurement, Supply Chain, Human Resources, Sales and Services, Marketing and E-Commerce, Development, and Consulting.  Apart from some of the use cases described before, a detailed list of business use cases are available through URL => https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/use-cases.html

Joule's interaction pattern:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html

Joule's interaction pattern can vary from:

  1. Informational: The Joule provides answers to factual questions (e.g. "What are the key rules for a team outing?")

  2. Navigational: The Joule guides users through a multi-step process or an internal journey, like approving a request or changing organizational data. (e.g. “Where in the app do I send a promotion request?”)

  3. Transactional: The Joule engages in task completion workflows, e.g. reviewing and updating position details (job title, department, cost center), then confirming by saying “Done”. It also supports user edits and next steps before finalizing. (e.g. “Update the position title to Sustainability Supply Chain Consultant — ready to submit?”)

  4. Analytical: The Joule offers data insights, metrics, and visual analytics, such as attrition trends vs. hiring rates charted by quarter. It helps users interpret numbers and trends. (e.g.“What was our quarterly attrition rate in 2024?”)

SECTION 3: Joule architecture

Image source: Joule learning journey 

Joule architecture consists of key components which work together to respond to a user's question.

  1. Scenario Catalog: The Scenario Catalog holds information about all the available scenarios, functions, and skills in SAP cloud applications. In helps to distinguish between different user questions and guides Joule to understand the request and connect it to the right action or system or workflow. This acts like a blueprint that maps user queries to the appropriate actions, destinations, or logic within SAP systems. For example, if a user query is "Retrieves the current leave balance for a given employee", then this gets mapped as below:
    1. Scenario: 'Get_Employee_Leave_Balance'
    2. Business application : Human Resource
    3. 'leave balance': Employee ID, leave Type and Date Range.
  2. Knowledge Catalog: This contains SAP-knowledge as well as the customer-owned knowledge. It is a collection of documents and content sources (often unstructured or semi-structured) that are made available to Joule for question-answering using RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) techniques. It supports Joule in answering open-ended, natural language questions that aren’t directly tied to structured data or APIs. For example, it can have a company's HR policies (e.g., leave, travel, benefits), Finance guidelines (e.g., expense reimbursement rules) and so on. These documents are chunked and vectorized using embeddings in HANA vector database as specified earlier. When a user asks a related question, Joule retrieves relevant chunks and sends them to the LLM to generate a grounded answer.
  3. User Context: This helps joule to contextualize a user's question. This includes information about the SAP cloud applications the user is currently using, along with any additional SAP applications the customer has licensed and activated for use with Joule. Joule also recognizes the user’s roles and permissions, ensuring they can access only the information or perform the actions they are authorized to within the SAP cloud environment. Additionally, Joule takes into account the user’s chat history and context to provide most relevant and accurate responses to user queries. To put in other words, a user will be able to view or perform any tasks only if they are authorized to do so based on their existing authorization. 
  4. Document Grounding: Large Language Models (LLMs) are generally capable of understanding prompts and generating human-like responses. However, they often lack the context and specificity needed for business scenarios. To address this, Joule uses a technique called document grounding. This allows Joule to generate more accurate and relevant responses by referencing business documents stored in SAP and third-party repositories. As part of document grounding, customers can upload their own content (such as HR policies, travel policies, service manuals, etc.). When an end user asks a question, Joule searches these documents for relevant information and returns a concise, natural-language response, including the source references. This ensures the answers are grounded in the customer's own structured and unstructured data, making them more trustworthy and context-aware.
  5.  Grounding: This is the process of combining generative LLMs with advanced information retrieval techniques to enhance the accuracy and relevance of responses—without the need to train or fine-tune the model on company-specific data. It leverages a customer’s internal knowledge sources (e.g., policies, FAQs, training material) to supplement the LLM’s existing knowledge. This improves the model’s reliability and ensures that responses reflect the customer’s unique business context.
  6. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): RAG is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). As part of the RAG, Document Grounding is performed. In this step, RAG is provided with relevant documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are chunked into smaller parts and then embedded into dense, continuous vectors—known as embeddings—which represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query.
  7.  HANA Vector Database: It enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords. For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. When a user asks about their leave balance, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.
  8.  Knowledge Graph: This graph is a semantic network that connects entities (like customers, products, orders, employees, etc.) and defines how they are related. This helps Joule go beyond keyword matching or document lookup. It actually lets Joule "understand" business context and structure.  Joule uses the graph to understand how different entities are linked (e.g., “Employee X belongs to Department Y” or “Invoice A is tied to Purchase Order B”). With this, Joule disambiguate questions and provide more accurate answers.  It also enables logical inferences, like “Show me all open invoices for suppliers in Germany”, “List products related to a delayed shipment” etc. Even if the data is spread across multiple systems, the graph can link them together efficiently.

 

 

Image sources: Knowledge Graph or Vector Database… Which is Better? and  GraphRAG: The Marriage of Knowledge Graphs and RAG: Emil Eifrem

NOTE: While RAG brings in document-based context and vector search finds the right text chunks, the Knowledge Graph brings in structure and relationship-based logic. Eg: RAG may find a document about a purchase policy, but the Knowledge Graph helps determine which department owns that policy and who can approve it.

Does LLM gets trained with SAP's data?

When SAP’s AI assistant Joule interacts with a Large Language Model (LLM), it doesn’t send data for storage or training. Instead, it shares information only briefly, as part of a prompt during runtime. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time, but it doesn’t remember or learn from what it receives. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data.

Joule's orchestration layer:

Image source: Examining how to onboard and extend Joule | AI105

Steps involved within Joule for processing user query:

  1. User submits query in natural language via Joule client in SAP cloud apps
  2. The prompt is sent to the Dialogue Management system, which manages the conversation flow and understands the user's intent.
  3. The Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) service forms a semantic vector search query based on the user input.
  4. This query is executed against a Vector Database where document embeddings are stored. The relevant document extracts are retrieved. These embeddings were created earlier from company-specific or SAP documents using document grounding
  5. The retrieved document snippets are passed along with the original prompt to a Large Language Model. The LLM uses the relevant extracts to ground its response (ensuring the response is based on actual documents, not hallucinations).
  6. The LLM generates a natural-language answer, grounded in the retrieved documents.
  7. The final answer is displayed to the user with source links and supporting documents attached.->Example: A link to a company travel policy PDF is shown under “Source Document”.

For more information, refer to Provisioning and Implementing Joule learning journey 

Deep dive into SAP Joule possible workflow to respond to any user prompt

SECTION 4: Joule packages and pricing: Base and premium

Joules comes in 2 different packages for consumption:

  1. Joule Base (No additional cost involved)
  2. Joule Premium

A. SAP Joule Base package: 

Joule Base package is available as supplement to all eligible SAP cloud subscriptions at no additional cost. As a prerequisite customer must have an active subscription to a supported SAP cloud product (e.g., SAP SuccessFactors).

  5. Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Streamline the informational, navigational, and transactional tasks.

entry.title: Expanding Data Federation for Broader Coverage with the New Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) has played a pivotal role in data federation, serving as a cornerstone for positioning SAP HANA Cloud as a single gateway to all data. As highlighted in my previous blog, Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud, SDA has also established itself as the core component for leveraging the full potential of data in the context of Clean Core.

Nevertheless, due to its limited protocol boundary to ODBC and REST, along with restrictions on running third-party drivers within the SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud, the supported scope of remote sources has been limited in SAP HANA Cloud.

This limitation has been complemented by SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) through its JDBC-based adapters, as it also supports data federation, even though SDI is primarily designed for real-time data replication. However, customers must deploy and operate Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) separately in an on-premise setup.

In this context, I'm pleased to announce that, starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, SDA now supports Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake as two new remote sources via a new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

In a nutshell, the new Data Access Agent was developed with the following three key characteristics.

  • Fully managed and secure: Like the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, this new Data Access Agent can be provisioned and deprovisioned in SAP HANA Cloud Central or via the Cloud Foundry Command Line Interface (cf CLI), but it operates separately. This separation helps ensure the SAP HANA database remains secure, as the Data Access Agent runs as a physically separate instance.
  • Greater flexibility: While the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST, this new Data Access Agent supports JDBC-based adapters. These will allow leveraging not only existing SDI adapters but also new third-party driver-based adapters.
  • Simplified operations: As this new Data Access Agent is managed by SAP in a cloud-native manner, the configuration and monitoring processes have become significantly more streamlined and user-friendly.

The good news is that support for remote sources to Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning. As described, since this new Data Access Agent introduces new possibilities for connecting to remote sources with different protocols, there are plans to support additional remote sources for data federation, including SharePoint in Microsoft 365, Google Sheets, and more.

However, please note that although this new Data Access Agent supports new JDBC-based adapters, it only supports data federation and snapshot replica toggling within the virtual table interface. That is, trigger-based real-time replication, like SDI, is not supported.
  

Getting Started with Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud

The first step to configuring remote source connections with the Data Access Agent is to ensure that the BTP subaccount is entitled to the service plan hana-data-access-agent. This is a prerequisite for using the Data Access Agent.

 

Create Data Access Agent:

If the service plan is correctly entitled, you can view and use the new Data Access Agent menu in the multi-environment edition of SAP HANA Cloud Central.

Now, you can proceed with the Create Data Access Agent button to provision a new Data Access Agent by entering its name and selecting one of the four preset size options.

The size of the Data Access Agent will depend on the workloads, and its capacity units (CUs) consumption will vary based on the selected size.

Please refer to the links below for further details, including sizing guidelines. Additionally, you can use the SAP HANA Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator (to be updated soon) to simulate the expected cost of a Data Access Agent for each size and monthly activity, even though the total estimate is already displayed on the right side of the above screen.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Setting Up the Data Access Agent

Once the name and size are decided, the next step is to register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud.

To register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, the corresponding SAP HANA database must be up and running. Additionally, the Data Provisioning Server must be enabled as a prerequisite. Another prerequisite is that the version of the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud must be QRC 02/2025 or later.

Otherwise, it cannot be selected or registered. The reason for being unable to register is also shown in the Details column.

Another important consideration is that a single Data Access Agent can only be registered to one SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. Once registered, the registration cannot be changed to a different SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. This means that for another SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, a new Data Access Agent must be created from scratch. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents, if needed.

After selecting the SAP HANA database instance to register, the next step is to enable adapters to access remote sources.

In the first release of the Data Access Agent, two adapters are available, as mentioned above. One is the AzureSQL adapter, which is used for accessing the Microsoft Azure SQL Database. The other is the Snowflake adapter, which is used for accessing Snowflake.

Adapters can be enabled or disabled later, even after the creation of the Data Access Agent. As previously mentioned, many more adapters will become available in the future.

Alright, that’s all for creating or provisioning a Data Access Agent.

Once the Data Access Agent is up and running, everything is set for creating remote sources and virtual tables. This process is not new and is essentially the same as using SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) or SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).
 

Create a remote source:

-- create a remote source to Snowflake
CREATE REMOTE SOURCE "Snowflake" ADAPTER "Snowflake"
AT LOCATION AGENT GROUP "demo-daa"
CONFIGURATION 'url=https://<myorganization-myaccount>.snowflakecomputing.com;
database=<database_name>;account=<account_name>;auth_type=Password'
WITH CREDENTIAL TYPE 'PASSWORD' USING 'user=<user_name>;password=<password>';

The above example shows how to create a remote source for Snowflake using the CREATE REMOTE SOURCE statement.

Similar to other SDA or SDI remote sources, it can be created using the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI, and remote objects can be retrieved.

Since the syntax and parameters for creating a remote source vary depending on the remote source, please refer to the links below for further details.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create an Azure SQL Remote Source
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Snowflake Remote Source
     

Create virtual tables:

Once the remote source is created, virtual tables can be created using either the CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE statement or the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI.

However, since creating virtual tables and generating statistics are essentially the same as with other SDA adapters, I will not cover these topics in this blog. Please refer to my previous blog or the links below for more information.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Virtual Table
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create Statistics on a Virtual Table or Linked Database
     

FAQs

Q: Do you have plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent, similar to SDI? If so, will SDA replace SDI?
A: No, there are no concrete plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent. As described, the Data Access Agent is intended only for data federation.

Q: It sounds like this new Data Access Agent is a cloud version of DPAgent. Is that the right understanding?
A: The new Data Access Agent can, to some extent, be logically regarded as a cloud version of DPAgent, but it is solely for data federation, as explained. It has been adapted and enhanced to support completely new remote sources, such as Snowflake. Furthermore, support for SharePoint in Microsoft 365 (e.g., list and Excel worksheet), Google Sheets, and more will follow. These remote sources have never been supported via SDI and DPAgent, although SharePoint has been supported for specific formats, such as CSV.

Q: It seems that with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, two new adapters can be enabled with the Data Access Agent. Does enabling an adapter incur additional costs?
A: No, enabling adapters does not incur any additional cost. In other words, regardless of how many new remote resources SAP supports by introducing new adapters via the Data Access Agent in the future, they will not incur any additional cost. Customers only need to pay for running the Data Access Agent itself.
However, the recommended number of adapters may vary depending on the size of the Data Access Agent. To ensure performance and efficient resource utilization, we plan to provide guidance or impose restrictions on the maximum number of adapters based on the size of the Data Access Agent if more adapters are introduced in the future.

Q: What will happen to the existing native ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters? Will they be discontinued or replaced with the new Data Access Agent-based adapters?
A: No, the existing native built-in ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters will continue, and even new remote source support can be introduced as a native built-in ODBC or REST-based SDA adapter. SAP will choose the best protocol when introducing support for a new remote source for data federation. In other words, newer remote sources can be supported either natively (via ODBC or REST) or through the Data Access Agent (via JDBC).

Q: Do you have plans to support the same capability (e.g., the Snowflake adapter via Data Access Agent) with SAP HANA Platform 2.0? Or can I register this new Data Access Agent with SAP HANA Platform 2.0?
A: No, these features are exclusive to SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud.

Q: Can I use a single Data Access Agent with multiple SAP HANA databases in SAP HANA Cloud?
A: No, as already explained, a single Data Access Agent can only be registered with a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents.
 

Conclusion

In summary, the newly developed Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud significantly enhances secure, flexible, and simplified access to remote data sources in a cloud-native manner. Its fully managed, physically separate service ensures the security of the SAP HANA database while supporting seamless provisioning and operation. With protocol flexibility, including JDBC-based adapter support, it enables integration with both existing SDI adapters and new third-party drivers. Its cloud-native design also simplifies configuration and monitoring, reducing complexity for users.

Support for Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning, with plans to expand to additional remote sources like SharePoint in Microsoft 365 and Google Sheets, further broadening data federation capabilities. However, it is important to note that this new capability focuses on data federation and snapshot replica toggling and does not support trigger-based real-time replication, as SDI does.

This innovation reaffirms SAP’s commitment to enhancing data integration while simplifying cloud-based processes, paving the way for more robust and dynamic data connectivity.

entry.title: How Retro Gamers Solved Time-Travel Debugging in 1995 (And Why Your Enterprise Debugger Still Can't)
entry.content:
A Tale of Two Debuggers

Scene 1: A modern enterprise developer in 2025, debugging a critical SAP integration. "If only I could go back in time and see what happened," they sigh, adding another log statement.

Scene 2: A 14-year-old in 2005, playing Super Mario on ZSNES. They press F1 to save state, die horribly, press F3 to load state, try a different approach. "Cool," they say, taking it completely for granted.

Welcome to the upside-down world where teenage gamers have better debugging tools than Fortune 500 companies.

TL;DR: github/ysichov/Smart-Debugger

https://github.com/ysichov/Smart-Debugger

The Secret That Wasn't a Secret

Here's what the retro computing community figured out decades ago:

Everything in a computer is deterministic except I/O.

That's it. That's the whole secret. Let me explain why this changes everything.

The Beautiful Math of Determinism

Same CPU state + Same memory + Same inputs = Same result
ALWAYS.

This means you don't need to record everything. You only need to record:

  • Initial state (once)
  • External inputs (keyboard, interrupts, timers)
  • I/O responses

For a Z80 system, that's maybe 100 bytes per second of recording. For an hour of debugging? About 360KB. That's smaller than a single Slack emoji.

The Timeline That Should Embarrass Us All

Let's put this in perspective with a side-by-side timeline:

🎮Gaming/Emulator World vs 💼 Enterprise World

1997

  • 🎮ZSNES: Save states introduced. Gamers can save/load any moment instantly
  • 💼Enterprise: "Have you tried adding more print statements?"

1999

  • 🎮Nesticle: Frame advance debugging. Step through games frame by frame
  • 💼Enterprise: "Maybe we should standardize on log4j?"

2003

  • 🎮FCEU: TAS* tools mainstream. Input recording, RAM watch, Lua scripting
  • 💼Enterprise: "Distributed debugging is impossible"

2004

  • 🎮MAME: Debugger with memory watchpoints, execution trace, state diffing
  • 💼Enterprise: "Remote debugging sometimes works if you're lucky"

2006

  • 🎮DeSmuME: Dual-screen debugging, touchscreen record/replay
  • 💼Enterprise: "Have you tried turning on verbose logging?"

2010

  • 🎮MAME: Full rewind feature. Go back in time at any moment
  • 💼Enterprise: "Debugging microservices is hard"

2014

  • 🎮BizHawk: Multi-system TAS suite. Deterministic replay across different CPUs
  • 💼Enterprise: "Maybe we need more logs?"

2018

  • 🎮RetroArch: Netplay with rollback, achievements system, shaders
  • 💼Enterprise: "Debugging in production is scary"

2020

  • 🎮TAS Bot: AI playing games frame-perfectly using debug tools
  • 💼Enterprise: "We added structured logging!"

2023

  • 🎮LibTAS: TAS tools for native Linux games, not just emulators
  • 💼Enterprise: "Time-travel debugging? Sounds futuristic!"

2025

  • 🎮Every emulator: Rewind, replay, Lua scripting, memory analysis standard
  • 💼Enterprise: "Our new AI can analyze your logs!"

 

The Tragedy in One Image

Teenager in 2004: *casually rewinds Mega Man X, 
                   adjusts one frame, gets perfect run*

Senior Developer in 2025: "The bug only happens in production 
                          on Tuesdays. We'll never catch it."

What Makes This Hilarious/Sad

A Nintendo emulator from 1998 can:

 

  1. Run Super Mario
  2. Let you save at any millisecond
  3. Rewind time
  4. Record and replay any bug perfectly
  5. Show you every memory change in real-time

 

Your enterprise debugger can:

 

  1. Set breakpoints (sometimes)
  2. Print variables (if you're lucky)
  3. Crash (frequently)

 

Enter Tool-Assisted Speedrunning: Debugging as Art

TAS creators took these debugging tools and turned them into an art form. Watch this:

They're not just playing games. They're:

  • Analyzing frame-by-frame execution
  • Tracking memory corruption
  • Exploiting race conditions
  • Optimizing code paths

Sound familiar? That's literally what we do when debugging, except they have better tools.

The ABAP Revolution: Finally, Someone Gets It

Yurii Sychov looked at ABAP debugging and had a radical thought: "What if we just... did what emulators do?"

His Smart-Debugger implements what gamers take for granted:

  • Variable time travel
  • Execution recording
  • State comparison
  • Visual debugging

But here's where it gets REALLY interesting...

The Memory Revolution: It's 2025, Not 1975

Modern servers have TERABYTES of RAM. An ABAP variable? Maybe 1KB. Even a complex object graph? Perhaps 1MB.

This means we can store:

 

  • Every variable change
  • Every method call
  • Every execution path
  • Multiple complete runs

 

Do the math:

 

  • 1000 variables × 1KB each × 1000 changes = 1GB
  • Your server's RAM: 512GB
  • Percentage used: 0.2%

 

We're optimizing for constraints that haven't existed for 20 years.

The Graph Diff Revolution

Now here's where it gets wild. Since we can store everything, we can:

1. Record Multiple Executions

abap

" Run 1: Bug happens
execution_graph_1 = record_full_execution( buggy_input )

" Run 2: Bug doesn't happen  
execution_graph_2 = record_full_execution( good_input )

2. Build Execution Graphs

Graph 1 (Buggy):
main() → parse_input() → validate() → process() → CRASH
         ↓                ↓           ↓
      [user_id: 123]  [cache: empty] [null_ptr]

Graph 2 (Working):
main() → parse_input() → validate() → process() → success()
         ↓                ↓           ↓
      [user_id: 123]  [cache: valid] [object_ref]

3. Diff the Graphs

diff

@@ -15,7 +15,7 @@
 validate() {
   check_permission()
-  load_user_context()  // ← Returns null in buggy run
+  load_user_context()  // ← Returns valid object
   verify_data()
 }

Key difference: cache state at execution time
Buggy:   cache.contains(user_123) = false
Working: cache.contains(user_123) = true

4. Compare with Static Analysis

Your static analysis says load_user_context() can never return null. Your execution trace says it did. Boom. Bug found.

The AI Cherry on Top

Now feed this to an LLM with structured data:

{
  "execution_diff": {
    "divergence_point": "load_user_context()",
    "buggy_state": {"cache": "empty", "result": "null"},
    "working_state": {"cache": "valid", "result": "user_object"},
    "static_analysis": "method cannot return null"
  },
  "context": {
    "method_signature": "load_user_context(): User",
    "cache_invalidation_log": ["14:23:15 - cache cleared", 
                               "14:23:16 - request received"]
  }
}

Prompt: "Based on execution diff, identify root cause"

LLM: "Race condition detected: Cache was invalidated at 14:23:15, but the null check in load_user_context() only verifies if cache exists, not if the specific key is present. The 1-second window allows requests to hit empty cache."

Automated RCA achieved.

But Wait, What About Reality?

"Sure," you say, "but emulators work with closed systems. What about network calls? Databases? Microservices?"

Fair point! Modern systems have more non-determinism. But that's exactly why we need BETTER recording, not worse:

The I/O Boundary Principle Still Applies

" Instead of just keyboard input, modern I/O includes:
IO_Events = {
  network_responses,     " Record actual HTTP responses
  database_results,      " Record query results  
  timestamp_calls,       " Record time() returns
  random_values,         " Record RNG outputs
  thread_scheduling      " Record context switches
}

Yes, it's more complex than a NES emulator. But the principle remains: Record at the boundaries, replay deterministically.

The Call to Revolution

Here's what we should be demanding:

For Every Debugger:

 

  • Time travel (perfected in emulators since ~2010)
  • Deterministic replay (standard in TAS tools since 2004)
  • State diffing (TAS creators do this manually)
  • Execution graphs (we have the memory!)
  • Automatic RCA (we have the LLMs!)

 

The Technical Requirements:

 

  • Record I/O boundaries (a few KB/second)
  • Snapshot on demand (even 1GB is nothing)
  • Build execution graphs (basic CS)
  • Diff and analyze (solved problem)

 

Start Today

 

  1. If you use ABAP: Get Smart-Debugger now ^_^
  2. For other languages: Demand better tools
  3. For tool creators: Study emulators, not enterprise

 

The Future Is Already Here

It's just unevenly distributed. And ironically, it's been living in game emulators for 30 years.

Next time someone tells you time-travel debugging is "too hard" or "too expensive," show them a 15-year-old speedrunner casually rewinding time to manipulate RNG in Pokémon. Then ask them why enterprise software can't do the same.

Memory is cheap. CPU is fast. The algorithms are known. The only thing missing is the will to build it.

Welcome to 2025. It's time to debug like it.

Your debugger doesn't suck because it's hard to build. It sucks because the culture around it never thought like a gamer. Time to change that.

entry.title: Why an organisation should always strive to keep a clean core in all transformation projects
entry.content:
What is a transformation Journey and why would a business choose to begin one?

There are many issues faced by businesses today in the ever-continuing goal to become ‘best run’. Some of these issues include natural disasters, geopolitical tensions such as tariffs, wars and other events that previously were once in a lifetime events, these are now the new common challenges of businesses in the modern age. Any one of these challenges or multiple of them combined can prompt a business to embark on a transformation journey.

An Enterprise small or big who wishes to unlock the full potential of their business in any sort of business landscape must leverage information technology as an important tooling. In a partnership with SAP, this enterprise can employ a guided transformation journey such as RISE with SAP. A transformation journey can be intimidating but with guided transformation journeys like RISE, the process can be simplified. [1]

Some motivations for the transformation could include:

  1. The Increasing Disruption of Global Supply Chains:
    Global supply chains are increasingly vulnerable to disruptions that highlight the critical need for resilience, agility, and the ability to adapt quickly. Events such as the EverGiven ship blockage in the Suez Canal illustrate how a single incident can unravel an entire organization crippling production schedules, depleting inventory levels, and significantly impacting customer satisfaction.
  2. Challenges in Meeting Evolving Customer Expectations:
    Modern businesses face a paradigm shift in managing customer expectations. The era of simple B2C (business-to-consumer) engagements has evolved into consumers demanding personalized solutions tailored to their specific needs. Additionally, customers expect businesses to prioritize sustainability and adhere to ethical practices, requiring organizations to be agile and responsive to changing societal demands. it is not enough for a business to simply sell shoes or clothes anymore. They need to ensure ethical sourcing and reduced carbon footprint for there entire chain of business.
  3. The Pressure to Keep Pace with Technological Advancements:
    Rapid technological advancements are transforming industries across the globe. Businesses must embrace innovation to stay competitive. whether that involves adopting AI-driven insights, enabling real-time data analysis, or leveraging automation to streamline operations. Falling behind in technology adoption not only puts companies at a disadvantage but can also limit their ability to innovate and scale efficiently.
  1. Some additional motivations for customers who undergo a transformation journey such as rise with sap could include the need for real time insights into their business, increasing the robustness and responsiveness of their systems, increased cloud flexibility and ability to maneuver operations to take advantage of new opportunities or to avoid potential downfalls.

Due to these challenges and new business opportunities a business might decide to embark on a transformation journey; from an old ERP System to a newer one in efforts to take advantage of the benefits of the cloud such as increased agility and ability to scale. [2] New modern comprehensive packages like S4HANA Cloud can provide this.  In this transformation journey, an important choice must be made. The choice is whether to opt for a brand-new implementation (greenfield) or a system conversion (“brownfield”) implementation strategy. [3] The challenges in keeping the core clean in these two implementation strategies are different.  [4]

While these benefits can be realized from a transformation process, they can be undermined by the negative effects that may arise if the customer fails to prioritize maintaining a clean core. Keeping the core processes clean and free of irrelevant customizations reduces technical debt, improved business adaptability and enables more agile businesses are key principles that define the importance of clean core. [5]

 

What is the clean core strategy and why is it necessary?

From the dawn of Enterprise Resource Planning “Keeping the core clean” has always been a goal. Although most businesses might believe they are completely different in terms of business structure or complexity, enterprise resource planning [6]

Clean core simply represents the ERP system without any baggage such as layers and layers of custom code, it means keeping your ERP System close to SAP Defined standard as much as possible while handling the integrations of extensions and modifications through SAP Defined best practices.  [5]. Clean means Up to date, transparent, unmodified, consistent, efficient and cloud compliant, Core means the main aspects of an ERP system landscape, the extensibility, data, integration and processes. [7]

Following a clean core strategy includes the active efforts to reduce data and process inconsistencies, establish suitable housekeeping processes and governance structures, maximizing the use of SAP’s standard functionality and minimizing the complexity of customization [7]

 

SAP’S Clean Core Approach.

A business operating at its optimal core will have an up-to-date system with cloud-compliant extensions and seamless integration. SAP for a long time has offered extensive capabilities for its software to be extended primarily through ABAP. Businesses were able to tailor the software to their specific market needs. However this freedom to customize however lead to significant long-term challenges that were expensive both financially and in terms of time. Customers who frequently customize functionality to align with a specific process result in the creation of thousands of custom objects, often lacking proper governance and documentation.

This technical debt can result in security vulnerabilities, degraded performance, and widespread system instability, making upgrades and transformations costly, complex, and time-consuming, effectively trapping companies in outdated software. Clean core emerged as a response to these challenges, addressing past architectural limitations by shifting from “in-core” ABAP customization to low-code, no-code, pro-code, and side-by-side solutions available on SAP BTP. [9]

 

 

Clean Core and its benefits during and after a transformation project.

There are multiple approaches to applying a clean core transformation; In a greenfield scenario, we can start from fresh and adopt a clean core from the beginning. This approach enables us to get all the key benefits of clean core right out of the box. On the contrary, however, a brownfield approach allows the new instance to maintain some of the old instance’s complexities and possibly unwanted customizations. In this scenario we must embark on a journey to get the core to become clean.  

Businesses may adopt a brownfield approach when existing processes are too complex or costly to restart, opting instead to preserve core operations. Yet even in these cases, maintaining a clean core is critical. A CTO evaluating the effort will inevitably ask: what is in it for us with clean core?

Keeping a clean core at heart implies a minimization of the need for custom code. Which directly translates into lower maintenance cost. This approach will reduce the total cost of ownership due to reducing maintenance. Also, technical debt which is the accrued cost of past fixes and nonstandard implementations, will also be a significant drain on the budget of an IT department saddled with an unclean core after a brownfield project is complete. [8]  

By working towards a clean core, organizations might begin to see a reduction in the total cost of ownership of the software and the ability to deploy its resources towards newer business issues rather than trying to solve the problem that comes from an accrual of technical debt. Keeping to the clean core emphasis on standard functionality helps in the development of a more robust and predictable system which directly enhances user productivity and satisfaction.

Keeping a clean core can enable more swifter updates. Some firms have reported cutting upgrade timelines by as much as 40%., traditionally as any large business who has implemented an ERP Solution will tell you upgrades are slow, and extremely expensive. Clean core changes this dynamic by decoupling custom logic which enables businesses to consume SAP’s Innovation rapidly. [8]

Having a clean core could also leave a business better equipped to handle various regulation and security standards. A clean core environment is easier to monitor as there are now clearer boundaries between the core ERP System. Reduced complexity will also lead to a higher level of security as fewer entry points are now present within the system. [8]

To support the clean core journey SAP, a strong advocate of maintaining a clean core both during and after a transformation provide instruments to enable the achievement and sustenance of clean core. In a clean core architected environment as recommended, the architectural approach as provided by sap supports the extension of features through well-defined public APIs, Business events which is a system generated notification in the ERP that something has occurred eg: a purchase order has been approved, or a goods movement has been posted.  [4]

External applications can subscribe to the event and trigger processes or workflows. This new approach by SAP removes the need for modifying the core of the software allowing for loose coupling. It enables businesses to react to change in real time without the need to modify the ERP of the software.

This approach means it is now easier to swap out, update or add new functionality with minimal disruption enabling the workforce to take advantage at any key moment of the new benefits offered by the cloud environment after a transformation project to S4HANA.

Beyond technical best practices the SAP clean core strategy of enabling teams to extend the system alongside the core rather than modifying it directly provides more room to build, test, and iterate without compromising stability. For example, one SAP customer experienced a four-month delay during a scheduled rollout due to dependencies tied to their legacy Z-code. Such delays can be costly in time, money, and momentum. By reducing reliance on core modifications, clean core emphasizes modular development, where individual components contribute to overall system agility.

Achieving and Sustaining Clean Core after the transformation project

 

 

The main goals to maintain clean core after the transformation.

Since our organizational goal is to achieve and maintain a clean core, it is essential to define the key components and indicators of a clean core, as well as the practices required to preserve it.

  1. Clean Extensions
  2. Clean Business Processes
  3. Clean Data

Clean Extensions: After the transformation journey is completed, a business need or requirement might provide a situation in which the business needs to add extensions to their ERP Systems. Extensions could help to meet various needs while providing immense value; but in order not to ruin the efforts we have undertaken so far to keep the core clean; it is important that we ensure they are implemented in a clean core compliant manner.

S4HANA is feature-rich, so organizations should critically assess the need for extensions before creating them, as the required functionality may already be available through SAP BTP. Extensions must be designed to support seamless ERP upgrades, avoiding risks or disruptions. Development teams should fully understand the requirements before starting and determine whether an extension should be implemented on-stack or side-by-side. Classical extension techniques are strongly discouraged, as they increase the likelihood of system instability, upgrade failures, and higher maintenance costs.

If, after evaluating all features, a business still requires extensions to meet its objectives, they should be implemented either internally within S4HANA Cloud as on-stack extensions or externally as side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP. SAP’s ABAP Cloud Development Model (CDM) enforces the use of released APIs and applies syntax checks to ensure compliance.

Keeping extensions clean is essential because poorly designed or non-compliant extensions can cause upgrade delays, break business-critical processes, introduce security vulnerabilities, and significantly increase long-term maintenance overhead. By minimizing unnecessary extensions, ensuring compliance with cloud standards, and aligning with customer requirements, organizations can maximize ERP effectiveness while maintaining a clean core.

 

Diagram of clean core extensibility with BTP.

Clean Business Processes: Organizations aiming to maintain a clean core must establish a strong organizational structure with clearly defined roles and responsibilities. This structure, combined with the selection of scalable, secure technological tools, forms the foundation for maintaining clean processes. During and after the transformation, tools such as Signavio Process Manager and Signavio Process Governance enhance process visibility, improve internal compliance, and accelerate business process optimization. [11]

By leveraging these solutions within a clean core environment, businesses can better understand their processes, identify root causes of issues more easily, and reduce both transformation time and risk outcomes that are far harder to achieve without a clean process core. Well-documented, efficient processes also help organizations remain competitive in a fast-paced business environment, ultimately leading to stronger results.

Clean Data: In the cloud and digital age, clean, usable data is one of the most valuable assets for organizations, enabling faster decision-making and actionable insights. Following a transformation to S4HANA Cloud, businesses gain a robust platform for managing, processing, and applying data effectively.

However, data is only as valuable as the processes and principles that ensure its cleanliness. The three main pillars of clean data are:

  • Accuracy: Data must reflect the true state of the business. Without proper validation rules, regular quality checks, and governance, inaccurate data can lead to faulty decisions, inefficient processes, and reduced user trust. Regular audits and automated checks help prevent these issues.
  • Completeness: Incomplete data undermines decision-making and trust. Businesses should enforce standardized data entry, validation processes, and comprehensive collection practices to maintain completeness.
  • Consistency: Data must be uniform across systems. Inconsistencies create confusion, errors, and inefficiencies. Maintaining standards, conducting profiling, and implementing integration and reconciliation processes are critical to consistency. [4]

Maintaining a clean core with respect to data maximizes the value derived from data, enhances process efficiency, and reduces total cost of ownership by enabling efficient management of data volumes and reliable results from business processes.

Conclusion

Regardless of the motivations for a transformation journey, maintaining a clean core during and after the process delivers significant organizational value. Beyond reducing total cost of ownership, a clean core enables the adoption of the latest innovations a critical advantage in the AI-driven era and provides the flexibility to meet evolving business objectives.

The five pillars of clean core represent more than a technological change; they signify a mindset and paradigm shift from on-premise to cloud-based systems. This shift affects custom code, data, processes, and overall business operations, keeping them effective and efficient.

When combined with a transformation initiative, a clean core unlocks a new operational paradigm, maximizing business potential and supporting the development of a sustainable, best-run enterprise. Given these combined benefits, it is clear that maintaining a clean core during a transformation journey is in the best interest of any organization.
